chapter.title: Spyware Blocker
chapter.para:
The Spyware Blocker Appliance is identified by the
symbol. If the Spyware Blocker Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

Spyware Blocker examines web requests from your protected network. As web resources are accessed, they are compared against several lists for suspicion of being spyware. Spyware Blocker looks for cookies from known spyware sites, URLs of known offenders, and ActiveX Controls known to be spyware applications. Spyware Blocker also examines the IP Address of the site being visited, and compares it against a list of offending subnets.
In the unusual event that a web site (legitimatly) visited by members of your organization is found in one of the Spyware Blocker Appliance's lists, administrators are able to create exception rules.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Spyware Blocker is presented as four tabs. The first two, and provide the administrator the ability to view/change sites which will or will not be considered spyware. The tab provides access to properties not directly related to spyware lists. The last tab, , allows administrators to view events (see ).

sect2.title: Block List
sect2.para: The block list tab presents administrators the ability to modify the four major categories of spyware blocking. Refer to the section for each sub-tab for more detail.

tip.para: If you wish to prevent a site from being categorized as spyware, it is recommended you not attempt to remove that site's data from one of the Block Lists. Instead, refer to on how to create exclusions to the blocking rules.

sect3.title: Cookie List
sect3.para: The Cookie List is a collection of IP Addresses and Hostnames. Should someone within the protected network visit one of these sites and that site attempt to set a cookie, ⪚ will prevent the cookie from being set. The interface for viewing and manipulating the cookie list can be seen in

As seen in , the Cookie List is presented as a table. The column labeled identification contains the address of the offending site. The next column, block, is used to enable/disable blocking of cookies from that site. Note that when creating a new entry, note that the value for identification can either be an IP Address (see ) or hostname.

tip.para: If you wish to prevent a site from being categorized as spyware, it is recommended you not attempt to locate that site in the cookie list and remove the entry. Instead, refer to on how to create exclusions to the blocking rules.

sect3.title: ActiveX List
sect3.para: The ActiveX List is a collection of ActiveX Control identifiers. When ⪚ encouters a page being fetched (from a machine within the protected network) with one of the listed ActiveX controls, that control is blocked. The complete interface for the ActiveX list is shown in .

As seen in , the ActiveX List is presented as a table. The column labeled identification contains the Object ID of the offending control. The next column, block, is used to enable/disable blocking of controls with that Object ID.

sect2.title: Pass List
sect2.para: The Pass List is used by administrators to declare those sites which should not be blocked as spyware. It is used in those rare circumstances where someone within the protected network needs to visit a site which is listed on one of the Block Lists. The complete interface for the Pass List is shown in

sect2.title: General Settings
sect2.para: The General Settings tab for the Spyware Blocker Appliance is shown in

There is only one setting on this tab, which allows administrators to disable all ActiveX controls. Setting this value (checking the box) causes ⪚ to block all ActiveX controls from being delivered to machines on the protected network.
